column3: The various ways the factory would hide the mistakes of the meat would be by pickling it to preserve it, using machinery, hot iron, and putting old meat into a blender and making it a sausage. The text says,"Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage – but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it "special," and for this they would charge two cents more a pound." (para 5) They constantly cut corners to make and extra buck. In the end the practices of the factory where all awful.
column4: The factory employed creative methods to conceal the errors of the meat production process. They pickled it to preserve it, used machinery, iron, and blender in various ways to disguise the flaws. Some sausages were prepared by smoking, but due to the lengthy process, the factory resorted to using chemicals to preserve the meat, adding color and texture to make it visually appealing. All the sausages were crafted from the same bowl, but they charged two cents more per pound for special packaging, hinting at the fact that the practices employed were quite expensive.

column4: These packing companies used various methods to eliminate odor from meat products. They employed chemical solutions, including soda and other substances, to render unpleasant smells undetectable. Additionally, they utilized a process called "thirty per cent pumping" to destroy odor through a stronger version of pickle. This technique significantly improved the quality of the meat products by eliminating unpleasant scents and enhancing their overall taste.

column3: Aristotle believed that an ideal tragedy should have a complex plan. He says that the plot should have huge swings in tone in order to keep the reader engaged. He also said, that the plots should not all be the same, but occassionally be in the reverse. For example, instead of going from bad to good fortune, make it good to bad. Lastly, Aristotle believed that having mutiple plots within one story could make the perfect tragedy.
column4: Aristotle believed that a tragic play should have a well-developed narrative structure with dramatic transitions. It should avoid repetitive or predictable plot developments. Instead, the narrative should alternate between different tones and themes, to keep the audience engaged and intrigued. Furthermore, Aristotle considered multi-layered storylines to be crucial in creating a grand and thematically profound tragedy.

column4: The social structure of ancient Egypt was a hierarchical system that determined the order of people within society. Those who worked the land were placed at the bottom of the pyramid, forced to engage in manual labor. However, they had the opportunity to improve their social standing through various avenues such as becoming merchants, artisans, physicians, or nobles. The social pyramid rose progressively as one gained higher positions in society.

column4: At the bottom of the societal hierarchy, slaves and farmers performed essential tasks that supported the entire society. While slaves constructed and maintained the physical infrastructure, farmers cultivated crops and livestock, contributing to the sustenance of the community. They were responsible for maintaining the health and defense of the populace, responding to emergencies and conflicts.

The nobles were wealthy and pleased the gods, while the farmers and others were paid taxes that amounted to a significant portion of their income. column4: The third wave developed because a teacher aimed to conduct an experiment on the students to investigate how people followed the crowd throughout history. They gave the students a clear set of instructions at different stages of the experiment to observe how they would react and interact with each other. The results were remarkable, demonstrating a significant improvement in the students' efficiency and orderliness, resulting in a noticeable decrease in their defiance and discipline. This observation also revealed that students became more actively engaged and disciplined while working on the project, leading to an exceptional display of loyalty and commitment to the task. However, due to the rapid dissemination of the project and the uncontrolled manner in which certain students became increasingly dominant, Jones had to terminate the experiment prematurely.

column3: The factories were a horrid place to be with ncredibly low health standards. column3: One element on an ideal tragedy is that it should be a complex story which imitates actions that will cause the audience to feel pity or fear.  Another element is that is should be a change of fortune from good to bad because of a great error. For example Oedipus, who once become a king, was blinded and banned which is the perfect set up for an idal tragedy. A final element, which is usually seen at the end of a tragedy, is an opposite catastrophe which which can either help or damage the main character.
column4: An ideal tragedy should be a rich narrative that evokes feelings of either pity or fear in the audience. It should also entail a significant shift in fate from a positive to negative destiny due to a profound misstep. Moreover, the tragedy should feature a predetermined path toward an unforeseen downfall that can either exacerbate or diminish the main character's situation.
